Lavrentiy Pavlovich Beria.Action: Politely points out a writer to add to the execution list, shows slight consideration by mentioning Stalin's liking of the writer’s work.
Carefully manages the list of names for Stalin's approval, showing attention to detail and some initiative by suggesting names but defers to Stalin's final decision.
Does not override Stalin's decisions even when he personally disagrees (e.g., keeping Shteyman on the list).
Stands quietly and watches as Khrushchev entertains others, possibly indicating a reserved or cautious approach in social/political settings.
Receives signed lists from Stalin and promptly states 'I'll have these dispatched.'
Picks up a forgotten list and jokingly comments about ensuring people don’t miss the party.
Orders senior NKVD officers to execute individuals in cruel and threatening ways, expressing pleasure at the thought.
Quickly spots an important document left behind by Stalin and takes it, ensuring no mistakes are made
Efficiently delegates lethal orders to NKVD officers, showing control and strategic thinking
Beria puts his arm round Khrushchev, laughing and sharing in a joke.
Jokingly demands Molotov to pay up on a bet, lightening the mood.
Mocking tone and teasing others, showing a playful but possibly insincere friendliness.
Laughs and engages in playful joking with Khrushchev, calling each other silly nicknames like 'Potato' and 'Tomato'.
Laughs and jokes with Khrushchev like two braying animals, engaging in childish behavior and not demonstrating serious leadership.
Mentions having a man shot for 'acquiring slippers' and warns never to joke about such matters.
Makes a darkly humorous comment about his men bringing in 'lots of lost sheep' implying arrests.
Addresses Molotov with a look of enigmatic menace and hints he will have plenty of time to sleep soon.
Confidently offers to have a task arranged ('I can have that arranged'), indicating control and decisiveness.
Discusses punishing a man for a seemingly trivial reason ('acquiring slippers') but stresses seriousness, showing awareness of the regime's paranoia.
Uses ambiguous, menacing body language ('a look of enigmatic menace'), projecting confidence and authority.
No clear mistake, failure or hesitation in the given excerpt.
Walking drunk and tired with other Politburo members, making a mocking joke impersonating Malenkov.
Does throat cutting gesture and says 'Goodbye, old friend. Goodbye forever.' about Molotov, treats death casually and callously.
Says 'Yep. On the list.' regarding Molotov's fate, and 'It would be simpler and cheaper if they just drove straight into a river. Sweet dreams!'
Makes a cold and decisive throat-cutting gesture and indicates Molotov is on the execution list, showing ruthless decisiveness and strategic confidence.
Jokes grimly about eliminating Molotov cheaply, demonstrating calculated and pragmatic thinking.
Yawns and strolls while cleaning his glasses, calmly gestures to a cell door as a crying woman is pushed inside by NKVD men.
Waves unconscious prisoner’s hand at another prisoner as a mocking 'goodbye' gesture.
Beria strolls along calmly, yawning and cleaning his pince-nez while overseeing the detention of prisoners, showing controlled composure and authority.
Confidently instructs that he will see the prisoner again in twenty minutes, indicating command over interrogation timing and procedure.
Shows no visible panic or confusion when prisoners are brought or detained; maintains a detached and composed demeanor throughout.
Massages the shoulders of a frightened prisoner and whispers in his ear.
Enters interrogation room, stands behind prisoner and massages his shoulders while whispering in his ear, demonstrating psychological manipulation and control.
Implied to have planted a tomato in Khrushchev’s pocket as a prank or insult, showing a confident use of petty tactics to undermine others.
Threatens prisoners violently and shows no sympathy during interrogation.
Gives strict, clear orders to subordinates to not interfere and to follow his instructions precisely.
Maintains composure and authority in a tense situation despite incoming news of Stalin's illness; gives clear, confident orders to Slimonov not to notify others or interfere.
Shows a brutal, intimidating interrogation style; uses physical violence and threats to extract information, displaying ruthless efficiency.
Orders the torture of Abramovsky and his wife to extract information.
Refers disdainfully to women cooperating to save their husbands, calling them 'devoted wives who go like sewing machines.'
Jokingly warns his second-in-command to watch his wife, suggesting mistrust.
Arrives confidently and determinedly at Stalin's dacha, commands soldiers firmly, secures the scene, and orders no one to enter, showing control and decisiveness.
Handles Matryona calmly and reassures her, showing emotional control and ability to manage tense situations.
Reassures Matryona that the Central Committee will handle things and that he will see to everything himself.
Makes a coarse comment about the smell in the room and refers to it as a 'Baku pisshouse'.
Handles Stalin's personal effects carefully, wiping his hand after pulling the key from a urine-soaked pocket; removes important secret files discreetly.
Uses a knife strapped to his calf to try and open a jammed window to pass documents secretly to Khrustalyov.
Threatens Khrustalyov aggressively to take the papers, indicating harshness rather than friendliness.
Keeps hold of Stalin's soiled hand respectfully despite discomfort, showing a degree of respect or duty.
Tests Malenkov by questioning his statements and instructing him to get used to challenges.
Sits luxuriating in Stalin's chair after throwing the papers into the stove, showing self-indulgence over empathy.
Makes a sarcastic remark about the absence of competent doctors due to previous purges, showing cold acknowledgment rather than concern.
Feeds documents through a window in a risky but effective way despite physical wobbling and almost falling, averting disaster at the last moment.
Threatens Khrustalyov to take the papers, demonstrating assertiveness and control over the situation.
Quickly disposes of incriminating papers by throwing them into the stove, showing decisiveness and presence of mind.
Luxuriates in Stalin's chair after destroying papers, showing confidence and a sense of power.
Kneels by Stalin’s hand even after realizing it is covered in urine, maintaining composure and control in a difficult situation.
Engages Malenkov in a verbal test to assess his readiness and mindset, demonstrating strategic thinking.
Sarcastically reminds Malenkov about the absence of competent doctors due to prior purges, revealing sharp awareness of political risks but also tacit critique.
Does not act immediately to summon a doctor despite the urgent medical situation, possibly indicating omission in crisis management.
Feels he should join the hug between Khrushchev and Malenkov but it does not come naturally.
Dismissively jokes about Khrushchev wearing pyjamas, mocking the situation and Stalin's condition.
Feels he should join in the hug but it doesn't come naturally; makes sarcastic comments about pyjamas and Malenkov being tested
Makes a sarcastic and mocking comment ('You think Stalin is... too heavy?') in a tense moment.
Engages in the discussion about Stalin's medical care and shows awareness of political implications, responding knowingly to the mention of Timashuk.
Describes a woman crudely and cynically as 'a desire to survive and blowjob lips.'
Suggests shooting the woman if things go badly, showing ruthless pragmatism.
Hangs back and quietly watches Stalin with a blank face, showing a moment of personal focus possibly beyond the group.
Suggests using a woman with questionable loyalty but useful skills, showing pragmatic ruthlessness and strategic thinking.
Calmly observes Stalin alone and confidently declares 'I'll take it from here' after others leave, showing self-assurance and readiness to lead.
Stops the laughter when Molotov's name comes up on a list, indicating seriousness about the situation.
Refuses to allow Stalin’s children to see him until they have a plan, showing a lack of tolerance or concern for family feelings.
Interrupts Khrushchev to loudly deny Stalin is dying, showing an attempt to rally and reassure, but in a forceful, insincere manner.
Declares Stalin is not dying and emphatically asserts control over the narrative, insisting on a plan before allowing contact with Stalin's family.
Interrupts Khrushchev and other members to dominate the conversation and manage the group's reaction to Stalin's condition.
Uses forceful language and rhetorical confidence to maintain order among committee members.
Refuses to allow Stalin's family to be contacted until a plan is in place, demonstrating control and strategic thinking.
No direct actions or statements in the excerpt indicating warmth; presence implied via NKVD men actions but no personal behavior detailed.

Mocks Khrushchev by calling him a 'pinhead' and undermining his reputation.
Confidently undermines Khrushchev and manipulates Malenkov by reminding him Stalin chose him, showing his political skill and influence.
Engages in crude humor and banter with Malenkov, potentially asserting dominance and easing tension, demonstrating social adeptness.
Is recognized by others as a significant threat or power player, implying a strong position within factional struggles.

Shepherds Svetlana inside, preventing Khrushchev from taking her hand.
Tetchily tells Khrushchev to see to contacting Vasily.

Comforts Svetlana who is crying, offers calm presence.
Interrupts and directs a doctor to 'put him out of his misery' in a blunt manner.
Nods to Lidiya to put Stalin out of his misery, indicating decisiveness and control over a difficult medical and political situation.
Disputes Khrushchev's claim that he got the doctors, defers credit to Malenkov, showing political tact and awareness of others' roles.
Speaks quietly and calmly to Lukomsky to get a direct answer about Stalin's recovery

Asks directly about Stalin's chance of recovery with calm and firmness, quickly understands the situation and announces its end decisively.
Has NKVD agents discretely positioned and ready to act on his signal, showing strategic foresight and control.

Discretely deploys and withdraws his people multiple times, showing careful management of resources and covert operations.
Does not explicitly communicate detailed plans for control or transition of power beyond immediate responses, missing an opportunity for transparent leadership.
Tells Lidiya to stay and shut her ears before he takes control of the situation and issues orders for a city-wide NKVD lockdown and arrests.
Punches the air with joy quietly after Stalin’s death, indicating personal excitement over the power shift.
Orders the immediate sealing of Moscow and replaces army stations with NKVD control, initiating new lists and arrests quickly after Stalin's death.
Acts with controlled joy and confidence, managing the coup with clear, decisive commands and strategic planning.
Maintains a calm and dismissive demeanor when an explosion occurs, shrinking potential panic by attributing it casually to an animal and quickly orders his NKVD officers without showing alarm.

Watches events unfold quietly from outside the dacha without immediate direct intervention, suggesting strategic restraint or possible passivity.

Moves others out of the way to take pride of place by Stalin's head at his revival.

Paces agitatedly and shows internal trouble for the first time.

Bangs on window loudly to call guards while under threat, attempting to assert control aggressively.
Maintains composure and does not lash out verbally under provocation, despite being hit and restrained.
Acknowledges collective guilt ('Exactly. Collective guilt.'), showing some recognition of shared responsibility rather than solely blaming others.
Bangs on the window calling for guards during his arrest, appears desperate but still tries to assert control.
Stares unemotionally at Malenkov who starts to cry, indicating emotional control amidst crisis.
Despite being beaten and handcuffed, tries to maintain composure and speak calmly.
Fails to prevent his arrest and capture by Zhukhov and others, losing command of the situation.
Has a knife strapped by his ankle, implying readiness for self-defense or escape attempt.
Tries to call after the people leaving the wrong room.
His forces (NKVD) aggressively arrest a man playing chess with his son, ignoring the wife's pleas.
There is no direct intervention or show of empathy when his son Vasily is violently arrested and dragged out of his house.
Is humiliated publicly, struggles with dignity, but attempts to discuss matters rationally.
His terrified staff and family are dragged out at gunpoint from his house.
Struggles physically and verbally when being arrested, unable to maintain composure or control.
Attempts to discuss situation rationally during capture, showing some presence of mind.
Brought to trial quickly, indicating opposition to his competence and influence, struggles with his trousers while being led out, showing some lack of control and composure.
Appeals to the emotions of others by mentioning their wives and children.
Shouts and curses at Malenkov, calling him a traitor during the trial.
Demands his legal rights and to be heard, invoking rules and fairness.
Tries to assert his legal rights and demands to be heard in the improvised courtroom despite hostile conditions.
Shows weakness and desperation when appealing emotionally to Malenkov about their wives and children, indicating loss of composure.
Able to verbally confront and curse Malenkov even while being restrained and humiliated, showing some confidence and defiance.
Physical stumble and loss of composure when dragged in by the generals, trouser falling and tripping, indicating clumsiness or vulnerability.
Mocks accusations sarcastically and refuses to show remorse, deflecting blame onto others.
Desperately calls Khrushchev 'friend' during his arrest and execution.
Breaks down screaming when threatened with a knife, showing vulnerability.
Attempts to deflect serious accusations with sarcasm and denial, but quickly becomes visibly shaken and loses composure.
When confronted with overwhelming accusations and imminent death, he breaks down and screams, failing to maintain control in a critical situation.
Initially tries to assert friendship with Khrushchev and protest the charges, indicating a degree of confidence before being overwhelmed.
